title: Walter Parke
text:
Walter Evelyn Parke (27 July 1891 – 13 October 1914) was an <a href="English%20people">English</a> first-class cricketer and <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer. Parke served in the <a href="Durham%20Light%20Infantry">Durham Light Infantry</a>, seeing action in France during the opening stages of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>. He was killed in October 1914. He also played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for the <a href="British%20Army%20cricket%20team">British Army cricket team</a>.
Life and military career.
The son of the <a href="Minor%20Counties%20of%20English%20and%20Welsh%20cricket">minor counties</a> cricketer Lieutenant Colonel Lawrence Parke and his wife, Evelyn Jane Aelfrida, he was born at <a href="Wimborne%20Minster">Wimborne Minster</a>. He was educated at <a href="Winchester%20College">Winchester College</a> from 1905–09, where he captained the college cricket team in his final year. Additionally, he played golf for the college and was appointed a prefect. From Winchester he attended the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>. He graduated into the <a href="Durham%20Light%20Infantry">Durham Light Infantry</a> as a <a href="Second_lieutenant%23United_Kingdom_%26amp%3B_other_Commonwealth_countries">second lieutenant</a> in August 1911. He made a single appearance in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for the <a href="British%20Army%20cricket%20team">British Army cricket team</a> against <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a> at <a href="Fenner%27s">Fenner's</a> in 1914. Batting twice in the match as an <a href="Batting_order_%28cricket%29%23Opening_batsmen">opening batsman</a>, he was dismissed for 11 runs by <a href="Gordon%20Fairbairn">Gordon Fairbairn</a> in the Army's first-innings, while in their second-innings he was dismissed 7 runs by the same bowler. 
He served in the 2nd Battalion, Durham Light Infantry during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, proceeding to France in September 1914. He had been promoted to the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in August 1914. He was killed while attempting to lift a machine gun over a hedge near <a href="Hazebrouck">Hazebrouck</a> on the afternoon of 13 October 1914, while commanding the machine gun section. His initial burial site at the <a href="Vieux-Berquin">Vieux-Berquin</a> crossroads was the subject of a famous photograph of two young French girls tending to his grave. His body was subsequently moved to the Outtersteene Communal Cemetery Extension at <a href="Bailleul%2C%20Nord">Bailleul</a>.
